front.div:
Abstract: (1 → 3)-β -D-Glucans, a cell wall component in most microfungi, are suggested to play a role in the development
of respiratory and general symptoms in organic dust-related diseases. The mechanisms by which they induce these effects
are, however, not clear. In the present study, mediator release and its potentiation by the (1 → 3)-β -D-glucan as well as by
the (1 → 6)-β -D-glucan found in yeast and other fungi were therefore examined. Blood leucocytes from healthy volunteers
and from patients allergic to house dust mite were incubated with (1 → 3)-β -D-glucans with increasing 1,6-branchings: curdlan
[a linear (1 → 3)-β -D-glucan], laminarin and scleroglucan, and furthermore with pustulan, a linear (1 → 6)-β -D-glucan. Histamine
release was not observed on exposure to the glucans only, but in the presence of anti-immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibody or
specific antigens, all the glucans investigated led to an enhancement of the IgE-mediated histamine release. The glucans
induced a significant potentiation of the mediator release when present at concentrations in the range of 2–5 × 10
− 5 M.
These results suggest that (1 → 3)-β -D-glucan as well as (1 → 6)-β -D-glucan aggravates IgE-mediated histamine release.
Knowledge concerning the effects of glucans on immune responses may be of importance for understanding and treating
inflammatory and allergic diseases.

(1 → 3)-β -D-Glucan is a cell wall component found in most
microfungi. In damp and mouldy buildings, the glucan has
been used as a putative marker of microfungal growth in the
examination of indoor mould exposure as a risk factor for
asthma and other adverse health effects [1– 4]. A relation has
been found between the indoor level of (1 → 3)-β -D-glucan
and the proportion of persons reporting symptoms indicative
of airway inflammation [1,2]. Upper airway inflammation,
verified by nasal lavage, has also been found in waste and
compost workers exposed to bioaerosols containing (1 → 3)-
β -D-glucan, endotoxins and fungal spores, indicating a
possible role of these agents in the inflammatory response
[5,6]. The ability of (1 → 3)-β -D-glucan to induce histamine
release has not been investigated, but the production of
cytokines upon exposure to (1 → 3)-β -D-glucans has been
